title: Six key projects by Winka Dubbeldam, SCI-Arc's next Director/CEO
author: Josh Niland
excerpt: Earlier this week, SCI-Arc announced the appointment of Winka Dubbeldam as the school's next Director and CEO. In light of her new leadership position, it's time for a look at some of her firm Archi-Tectonics' most recognized projects completed since its founding in...
text: Earlier this week, SCI-Arc announced the appointment of Winka Dubbeldam as the school's next Director and CEO. In light of her new leadership position, it's time for a look at some of her firm Archi-Tectonics' most recognized projects completed since its founding in 1994.  Since that time, honors from numerous design awards have helped propel the firm into the international spotlight, highlighting in turn Dubbeldam's profile as an architect. The studio, whose operations are spread between New York, Amsterdam, and Hangzhou, is set to publish their first monograph Monsters and Mutants (via Park Books, Switzerland) later this year. London Solar House in London (completed 2024) London Solar House. Photo: Nick KaneLondon Solar House. Photo: Nick KaneIn search of the most ergonomic and frugal housing unit, the firm first maintained the solid masonry structure of the original two-story building as the gravitational core, forming a largely opaque boundary of the building, from which a new roof extension and other building projections materialize. These new geometries translate between the adjacent townhouses to form a multifaceted, folded zinc and glass envelope, thus creating at once continuity and a somewhat strange "otherness" within the existing context.Asian Games 2022 Master Plan and Hybrid Buildings in Hangzhou (completed 2023) Asian Games 2022 Master Plan and Hybrid Buildings. Photo: SFAP ShanghaiAsian Games 2022 Master Plan and Hybrid Buildings. Photo: SFAP ShanghaiThis 116-acre eco-park in Hangzhou, China, was designed to serve both the 2022 Asian Games and the city's long-term urban and environmental goals. The master plan integrates seven buildings—including two hybrid stadiums, a fitness and visitor center, a sunken shopping mall, and parking garages—into a landscape that emphasizes sustainability and public engagement. The design leverages Kongjian Yu's 'Sponge City' concept to manage stormwater and enhance biodiversity. Post-Games, the park offers amenities like playgrounds, hiking trails, and concert spaces, ensuring its continued use as a vibrant community hub.  Hybrid Stadium & Concert Hall in Hangzhou (completed 2023) Hybrid Stadium & Concert Hall. Photo: SFAP ShanghaiHybrid Stadium & Concert Hall. Photo: SFAP ShanghaiThe 6,500-seat centerpiece for the Hangzhou Asian Games 2023 Park was created as both "an icon for the games and an active participant in Hangzhou's urban landscape that would generate new activities and uses once the games end," in the words of Dubbeldam.  Its geometry was refined through multiple iterations and produced a distinctive asymmetric shape. Bowl seating merges the arena and amphitheater seating components, making it possible to adapt the layout for sporting events into an asymmetric, stage-centered configuration for performances. The double-curved inner bowl is entirely clad in locally sourced bamboo with recessed lighting and a skylight, blending digitally generated forms with other vernacular materials that offer a "warm and inviting environment." 512 GW Townhouse in New York City (completed 2020) 512 GW Townhouse. Photo: Archi-Tectonics | Federica Carlet512 GW Townhouse. Photo: Archi-Tectonics | Federica Carlet(Per the architects) "By adding a large extension onto an existing building with a modest footprint of 19 x 40 feet, we converted the building into an 8-story townhouse for 1 family, wrapped by a spacious lattice envelope functioning as a climatic skin, a third 'building.'A glass elevator connects the floors with connective voids that allow for a fluid living environment. The highly recognizable climate envelope, whose spatial and performative properties serve as an adaptable perimeter of the building, is made from a lightweight steel frame and folding panels. This skin can be opened and closed with ease, and adds new exterior spaces in different, variable conditions. This project achieves 45% energy savings with an innovative operable folding screen that was integrated into a residential building." North Salem Residence and Landscape in Upstate New York (completed 2019) North Salem Residence and Landscape. Photo: Federica CarletNorth Salem Residence and Landscape. Photo: Federica CarletThis 4,070-square-foot residential design in the Lower Hudson Valley community of North Salem, New York, reimagines a classic home with a blend of modern elegance and contextual sensitivity. The interior renovation introduces natural materials, brass fixtures, and custom furniture to create airy, relaxed spaces. Outside, sculptural Ipe hardwood fences follow the rolling terrain, offering both privacy and unobstructed views of the surrounding landscape. These interventions harmonize the home with its environment, reflecting a thoughtful integration of architecture and nature. V33 Residential Building in New York City (completed 2014) V33 Residential Building. Photo: Floto & Warner Photography | Eric van den Brulle | Archi-TectonicsV33 Residential Building. Photo: Floto & Warner Photography | Eric van den Brulle | Archi-TectonicsA standout within its urban context thanks to its tessellated facade, which provides the enclosure for seven 'urban villas', the design succeeded in complying with the Landmarks Preservation Commission’s stringent guidelines. The result, say the architects, is a 32,000-square-foot building whose varying height cantilever residential units offer some of the most "expansive living environments in the heart of the city." html:
Earlier this week, SCI-Arc announced the appointment of Winka Dubbeldam as the school's next Director and CEO. In light of her new leadership position, it's time for a look at some of her firm Archi-Tectonics' most recognized projects completed since its founding in 1994. 

Since that time, honors from numerous design awards have helped propel the firm into the international spotlight, highlighting in turn Dubbeldam's profile as an architect. The studio, whose operations are spread between New York, Amsterdam, and Hangzhou, is set to publish their first monograph Monsters and Mutants (via Park Books, Switzerland) later this year.

London Solar House in London (completed 2024)

Asian Games 2022 Master Plan and Hybrid Buildings in Hangzhou (completed 2023)

This 116-acre eco-park in Hangzhou, China, was designed to serve both the 2022 Asian Games and the city's long-term urban and environmental goals. The master plan integrates seven buildings—including two hybrid stadiums, a fitness and visitor center, a sunken shopping mall, and parking garages—into a landscape that emphasizes sustainability and public engagement. The design leverages Kongjian Yu's 'Sponge City' concept to manage stormwater and enhance biodiversity. Post-Games, the park offers amenities like playgrounds, hiking trails, and concert spaces, ensuring its continued use as a vibrant community hub. 

Hybrid Stadium & Concert Hall in Hangzhou (completed 2023)

The 6,500-seat centerpiece for the Hangzhou Asian Games 2023 Park was created as both "an icon for the games and an active participant in Hangzhou's urban landscape that would generate new activities and uses once the games end," in the words of Dubbeldam. 

Its geometry was refined through multiple iterations and produced a distinctive asymmetric shape. Bowl seating merges the arena and amphitheater seating components, making it possible to adapt the layout for sporting events into an asymmetric, stage-centered configuration for performances. The double-curved inner bowl is entirely clad in locally sourced bamboo with recessed lighting and a skylight, blending digitally generated forms with other vernacular materials that offer a "warm and inviting environment."

512 GW Townhouse in New York City (completed 2020)

(Per the architects) "By adding a large extension onto an existing building with a modest footprint of 19 x 40 feet, we converted the building into an 8-story townhouse for 1 family, wrapped by a spacious lattice envelope functioning as a climatic skin, a third 'building.'A glass elevator connects the floors with connective voids that allow for a fluid living environment. The highly recognizable climate envelope, whose spatial and performative properties serve as an adaptable perimeter of the building, is made from a lightweight steel frame and folding panels. This skin can be opened and closed with ease, and adds new exterior spaces in different, variable conditions. This project achieves 45% energy savings with an innovative operable folding screen that was integrated into a residential building."

North Salem Residence and Landscape in Upstate New York (completed 2019)

This 4,070-square-foot residential design in the Lower Hudson Valley community of North Salem, New York, reimagines a classic home with a blend of modern elegance and contextual sensitivity. The interior renovation introduces natural materials, brass fixtures, and custom furniture to create airy, relaxed spaces. Outside, sculptural Ipe hardwood fences follow the rolling terrain, offering both privacy and unobstructed views of the surrounding landscape. These interventions harmonize the home with its environment, reflecting a thoughtful integration of architecture and nature.

V33 Residential Building in New York City (completed 2014)

A standout within its urban context thanks to its tessellated facade, which provides the enclosure for seven 'urban villas', the design succeeded in complying with the Landmarks Preservation Commission’s stringent guidelines. The result, say the architects, is a 32,000-square-foot building whose varying height cantilever residential units offer some of the most "expansive living environments in the heart of the city."

To explore even more Archi-Tectonics projects, visit the firm's profile on Archinect.
